Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: The nursing assistant is assigned to a patient in critical condition whose vital signs must be monitored every few minutes.
Story: I glance at the clock on the hospital wall, my heart pounding in time with the beeping monitors. As a nursing assistant, I know how crucial it is to keep a close eye on Mr. Lee, whose blood pressure has been dangerously unstable all morning. Every few minutes, I check his vitals, jotting down numbers, alert for the slightest change. But in the back of my mind, I can’t stop thinking about the home loan payment looming over me. Two months isn’t long, and I need to pick up extra shifts if I want to make sure my family doesn’t fall behind. My son’s school fees, groceries, the electricity bill—they all depend on me. Yet, if I ask for more hours, I’ll barely see my children, and the guilt gnaws at me. The hospital expects my full attention, but so does my family. I feel pulled in two directions, the weight of responsibility pressing down on my chest as I stand by Mr. Lee’s bedside, pen poised, mind racing.
